In Julia, Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

```julia
function timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime, bump = 3)
    if dt isa DateTime
        return dt + Hour(bump)
    elseif dt isa Date
        error("Date types are not supported by this function. Please provide a DateTime type.")
    end
end
```
This Julia function `timezone_bumper` takes a `DateTime` object and an integer (defaults to 3 if no argument is passed) as inputs. If the input is a `DateTime`, it increases it by the specified number of hours and returns the new `DateTime`. If the input is a `Date`, it throws an error because this function only supports `DateTime` objects.
